# The `TargetTransformInfo` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

This pass provides access to the codegen interfaces that are needed for IR-level transformations. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Declaration

<CodeBlock>class llvm::TargetTransformInfo</CodeBlock>

## Description {#details}

This pass provides access to the codegen interfaces that are needed for IR-level transformations.

Definition at line 212 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>.

### TargetTransformInfo() {#af1bf12b2f33b7e30f8f361a1e7642079}

  prototype="llvm::TargetTransformInfo::TargetTransformInfo (T Impl)">
Construct a <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#aa0d69e81725c10fa5407f0bf34462068">TTI</a> object using a type implementing the <code><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/targettransforminfo/concept">Concept</a></code> API below.

This is used by targets to construct a <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#aa0d69e81725c10fa5407f0bf34462068">TTI</a> wrapping their target-specific implementation that encodes appropriate costs for their target.

### hasArmWideBranch() {#a959a58a9740a235c53703a287e722906}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool TargetTransformInfo::hasArmWideBranch (bool Thumb) const">

<SectionUser title="Returns">
Whether a 32-bit branch instruction is available in Arm or Thumb state.
</SectionUser>

Used by the LowerTypeTests pass, which constructs an IR inline assembler node containing a jump table in a format suitable for the target, so it needs to know what format of jump table it can legally use.

For non-Arm targets, this function isn&#39;t used. It defaults to returning false, but it shouldn&#39;t matter what it returns anyway.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l01876">1876</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp/#l01382">1382</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp">TargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.

### getFlatAddressSpace {#a93e74cc1819ce2f8f151a1900284ce89}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="unsigned TargetTransformInfo::getFlatAddressSpace () const">
Returns the address space <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/callingconv/#abdf8cf606905c10634e831390981b0ed">ID</a> for a target&#39;s &#39;flat&#39; address space.

Note this is not necessarily the same as addrspace(0), which LLVM sometimes refers to as the generic address space. The flat address space is a generic address space that can be used access multiple segments of memory with different address spaces. Access of a memory location through a pointer with this address space is expected to be legal but slower compared to the same memory location accessed through a pointer with a different address space. This is for targets with different pointer representations which can be converted with the addrspacecast instruction. If a pointer is converted to this address space, optimizations should attempt to replace the access with the source address space.


<SectionUser title="Returns">
~0u if the target does not have such a flat address space to optimize away.
</SectionUser>

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l00478">478</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp/#l00315">315</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp">TargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getGEPCost {#a57fca44604259f23a346fdc969aaefeb}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getGEPCost (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; PointeeType, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; Ptr, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; &gt; Operands, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; AccessType=nullptr, <a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bb">TargetCostKind</a> CostKind=<a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba7f80055e1969cb850739546467460ad8">TCK&#95;SizeAndLatency</a>) const</>}>
Estimate the cost of a GEP operation when lowered.

<code>PointeeType</code> is the source element type of the GEP. <code>Ptr</code> is the base pointer operand. <code>Operands</code> is the list of indices following the base pointer.

<code>AccessType</code> is a hint as to what type of memory might be accessed by users of the GEP. getGEPCost will use it to determine if the GEP can be folded into the addressing mode of a load/store. If AccessType is null, then the resulting target type based off of PointeeType will be used as an approximation.

### getInlinerVectorBonusPercent {#aa30e16357eef0a6bb3dc98fb7fd67684}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="int TargetTransformInfo::getInlinerVectorBonusPercent () const">

<SectionUser title="Returns">
Vector bonus in percent.
</SectionUser>

Vector bonuses: We want to more aggressively inline vector-dense kernels and apply this bonus based on the percentage of vector instructions. A bonus is applied if the vector instructions exceed 50% and half that amount is applied if it exceeds 10%. Note that these bonuses are some what arbitrary and evolved over time by accident as much as because they are principled bonuses. FIXME: It would be nice to base the bonus values on something more scientific. A target may has no bonus on vector instructions.

### getInstructionCost {#ac77dbedcfd916a5c9b58e753b2678a98}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getInstructionCost (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/user">User</a> &#42; U, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; &gt; Operands, <a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bb">TargetCostKind</a> CostKind) const</>}>
Estimate the cost of a given IR user when lowered.

This can estimate the cost of either a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantexpr">ConstantExpr</a> or <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> when lowered.

<code>Operands</code> is a list of operands which can be a result of transformations of the current operands. The number of the operands on the list must equal to the number of the current operands the IR user has. Their order on the list must be the same as the order of the current operands the IR user has.

The returned cost is defined in terms of <code><a href="#ac44f6b9fdbb5f9cc199f8329cb0b272c">TargetCostConstants</a></code>, see its comments for a detailed explanation of the cost values.

### hasBranchDivergence {#a233996b13b5fa2774af23282d8870204}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::hasBranchDivergence (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> &#42; F=nullptr) const</>}>
Return true if branch divergence exists.

Branch divergence has a significantly negative impact on GPU performance when threads in the same wavefront take different paths due to conditional branches.

If <code>F</code> is passed, provides a context function. If <code>F</code> is known to only execute in a single threaded environment, the target may choose to skip uniformity analysis and assume all values are uniform.

Alternatively, we could split the cost interface into distinct code-size and execution-speed costs. This would allow modelling the core of this query more accurately as a call is a single small instruction, but incurs significant execution cost.

### enum  {#ac44f6b9fdbb5f9cc199f8329cb0b272c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="enum llvm::TargetTransformInfo::TargetCostConstants ">
Underlying constants for &#39;cost&#39; values in this interface.

<EnumerationList title="Enumeration values">

<Link id="ac44f6b9fdbb5f9cc199f8329cb0b272ca89f768b1267e3083b4eb05b4ab77e717" />
<EnumerationListItem name="TCC_Free">
<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/expected">Expected</a> to fold away in lowering (= 0)
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="ac44f6b9fdbb5f9cc199f8329cb0b272cae46c9eecc49bd2dc253c607e78a0fb86" />
<EnumerationListItem name="TCC_Basic">
The cost of a typical &#39;add&#39; instruction (= 1)
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="ac44f6b9fdbb5f9cc199f8329cb0b272ca022565d444ccf496c0414bccefbcd9c8" />
<EnumerationListItem name="TCC_Expensive">
The cost of a &#39;div&#39; instruction on x86 (= 4)
</EnumerationListItem>

</EnumerationList>

Many APIs in this interface return a cost. This enum defines the fundamental values that should be used to interpret (and produce) those costs. The costs are returned as an int rather than a member of this enumeration because it is expected that the cost of one IR instruction may have a multiplicative factor to it or otherwise won&#39;t fit directly into the enum. Moreover, it is common to sum or average costs which works better as simple integral values. Thus this enum only provides constants. Also note that the returned costs are signed integers to make it natural to add, subtract, and test with zero (a common boundary condition). It is not expected that 2^32 is a realistic cost to be modeling at any point.

Note that these costs should usually reflect the intersection of code-size cost and execution cost. A free instruction is typically one that folds into another instruction. For example, reg-to-reg moves can often be skipped by renaming the registers in the CPU, but they still are encoded and thus wouldn&#39;t be considered &#39;free&#39; here.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l00288">288</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### enum  {#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bb}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="enum llvm::TargetTransformInfo::TargetCostKind ">
The kind of cost model.

<EnumerationList title="Enumeration values">

<Link id="a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba59b32ea7b6f10564abd40ad90602ca5b" />
<EnumerationListItem name="TCK_RecipThroughput">
Reciprocal throughput
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba81b2c6f1f1e13e4a575e6d1c8b29b6e1" />
<EnumerationListItem name="TCK_Latency">
The latency of instruction
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba737cfc93e5a2ff961677d57186167e7c" />
<EnumerationListItem name="TCK_CodeSize">
<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> code size
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba7f80055e1969cb850739546467460ad8" />
<EnumerationListItem name="TCK_SizeAndLatency">
The weighted sum of size and latency
</EnumerationListItem>

</EnumerationList>

There are several different cost models that can be customized by the target. The normalization of each cost model may be target specific. e.g. TCK&#95;SizeAndLatency should be comparable to target thresholds such as those derived from <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/mcschedmodel/#a74a33138b76ebc2cae1b3cf65411a9e6">MCSchedModel::LoopMicroOpBufferSize</a> etc.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l00263">263</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>

  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getIntImmCodeSizeCost (unsigned Opc, unsigned Idx, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; Imm, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; Ty) const</>}>
Return the expected cost for the given integer when optimising for size.

This is different than the other integer immediate cost functions in that it is subtarget agnostic. This is useful when you e.g. target one ISA such as Aarch32 but smaller encodings could be possible with another such as Thumb. This return value is used as a penalty when the total costs for a constant is calculated (the bigger the cost, the more beneficial constant hoisting is).

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l01080">1080</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp/#l00718">718</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp">TargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.

### hasDivRemOp {#ac31bf22f119c5a99c36646d8e0eb2c0f}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::hasDivRemOp (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; DataType, bool IsSigned) const</>}>
Return true if the target has a unified operation to calculate division and remainder.

If so, the additional implicit multiplication and subtraction required to calculate a remainder from division are free. This can enable more aggressive transformations for division and remainder than would typically be allowed using throughput or size cost models.

### hasVolatileVariant {#ab33e1370498d06e0760c2861ff25e43a}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::hasVolatileVariant (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; I, unsigned AddrSpace) const</>}>
Return true if the given instruction (assumed to be a memory access instruction) has a volatile variant.

If that&#39;s the case then we can avoid addrspacecast to generic AS for volatile loads/stores. Default implementation returns false, which prevents address space inference for volatile loads/stores.

### isFPVectorizationPotentiallyUnsafe {#ab75d51988243f8ea9086b110401f8758}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool TargetTransformInfo::isFPVectorizationPotentiallyUnsafe () const">
Indicate that it is potentially unsafe to automatically vectorize floating-point operations because the semantics of vector and scalar floating-point semantics may differ.

For example, <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/arm">ARM</a> NEON v7 SIMD math does not support IEEE-754 denormal numbers, while depending on the platform, scalar floating-point math does. This applies to floating-point math operations and calls, not memory operations, shuffles, or casts.

### isLegalAltInstr {#aae67acb89326f200683e3d0b872a5329}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::isLegalAltInstr (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/vectortype">VectorType</a> &#42; VecTy, unsigned Opcode0, unsigned Opcode1, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallbitvector">SmallBitVector</a> &amp; OpcodeMask) const</>}>
Return true if this is an alternating opcode pattern that can be lowered to a single instruction on the target.

In <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/x86">X86</a> this is for the addsub instruction which corrsponds to a Shuffle + Fadd + FSub pattern in IR. This function expectes two opcodes: <code>Opcode1</code> and <code>Opcode2</code> being selected by <code>OpcodeMask</code>. The mask contains one bit per lane and is a <code>0</code> when <code>Opcode0</code> is selected and <code>1</code> when Opcode1 is selected. <code>VecTy</code> is the vector type of the instruction to be generated.

### enum  {#aa4c17e89b1ef061ed69f42b7cee93dbe}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="enum llvm::TargetTransformInfo::PopcntSupportKind ">
Flags indicating the kind of support for population count.

<EnumerationList title="Enumeration values">

<Link id="aa4c17e89b1ef061ed69f42b7cee93dbea0ce99a3a4fe2b7f2771a7b288a99ed2c" />
<EnumerationListItem name="PSK_Software">

</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="aa4c17e89b1ef061ed69f42b7cee93dbea01deb9d0bc6399399b0d8377bd09201d" />
<EnumerationListItem name="PSK_SlowHardware">

</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="aa4c17e89b1ef061ed69f42b7cee93dbeac71465fd61f1ba8aa2c7c397722b5e05" />
<EnumerationListItem name="PSK_FastHardware">

</EnumerationListItem>

</EnumerationList>

Compared to the SW implementation, HW support is supposed to significantly boost the performance when the population is dense, and it may or may not degrade performance if the population is sparse. A HW support is considered as &quot;Fast&quot; if it can outperform, or is on a par with, SW implementation when the population is sparse; otherwise, it is considered as &quot;Slow&quot;.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l00719">719</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### preferToKeepConstantsAttached {#a954be846c618b16d1e51108cf99168df}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::preferToKeepConstantsAttached (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &amp; Inst, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> &amp; Fn) const</>}>
It can be advantageous to detach complex constants from their uses to make their generation cheaper.

This hook allows targets to report when such transformations might negatively effect the code generation of the underlying operation. The motivating example is divides whereby hoisting constants prevents the code generator&#39;s ability to transform them into combinations of simpler operations.

### shouldTreatInstructionLikeSelect {#a50270e81abbcbbfe470af5ca01d54e75}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::shouldTreatInstructionLikeSelect (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; I) const</>}>
Should the Select Optimization pass treat the given instruction like a select, potentially converting it to a conditional branch.

This can include select-like instructions like or(zext(c), x) that can be converted to selects.

### enum class  {#af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>enum class llvm::TargetTransformInfo::CastContextHint : uint8&#95;t</>}
 labels = {["strong"]}>
Represents a hint about the context in which a cast is used.

<EnumerationList title="Enumeration values">

<Link id="af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64a6adf97f83acf6453d4a6a4b1070f3754" />
<EnumerationListItem name="None">
The cast is not used with a load/store of any kind
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64a960b44c579bc2f6818d2daaf9e4c16f0" />
<EnumerationListItem name="Normal">
The cast is used with a normal load/store
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64a6864311f985d160ad4bd46a9fbe4a4d4" />
<EnumerationListItem name="Masked">
The cast is used with a masked load/store
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64afc2e3edeec59afcdc10f55205713f14b" />
<EnumerationListItem name="GatherScatter">
The cast is used with a gather/scatter
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64ad392556b3674a98332cc2938ba0bfeb7" />
<EnumerationListItem name="Interleave">
The cast is used with an interleaved load/store
</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64a030aa94015bd11d183b897ddb541e4e3" />
<EnumerationListItem name="Reversed">
The cast is used with a reversed load/store
</EnumerationListItem>

</EnumerationList>

For zext/sext, the context of the cast is the operand, which must be a load of some kind. For trunc, the context is of the cast is the single user of the instruction, which must be a store of some kind.

This enum allows the vectorizer to give getCastInstrCost an idea of the type of cast it&#39;s dealing with, as not every cast is equal. For instance, the zext of a load may be free, but the zext of an interleaving load can be (very) expensive!

See <code>getCastContextHint</code> to compute a <a href="#af84cce349a77262269fd3f6756f37a64">CastContextHint</a> from a cast Instruction&#42;. Callers can use it if they don&#39;t need to override the context and just want it to be calculated from the instruction.

FIXME: This handles the types of load/store that the vectorizer can produce, which are the cases where the context instruction is most likely to be incorrect. There are other situations where that can happen too, which might be handled here but in the long run a more general solution of costing multiple instructions at the same times may be better.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l01389">1389</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getAddressComputationCost {#a246f298958a4a730bf7d3a64440dd47b}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getAddressComputationCost (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; Ty, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalarevolution">ScalarEvolution</a> &#42; SE=nullptr, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scev">SCEV</a> &#42; Ptr=nullptr) const</>}>

The cost of the address computation. For most targets this can be merged into the instruction indexing mode. The &#39;SE&#39; parameter holds pointer for the scalar evolution object which is used in order to get the Ptr step value in case of constant stride. The &#39;Ptr&#39; parameter holds <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scev">SCEV</a> of the access pointer.

### getAltInstrCost {#ac442c18de69f9270e02ee8e35113502c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getAltInstrCost (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/vectortype">VectorType</a> &#42; VecTy, unsigned Opcode0, unsigned Opcode1, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallbitvector">SmallBitVector</a> &amp; OpcodeMask, <a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bb">TTI::TargetCostKind</a> CostKind=<a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba59b32ea7b6f10564abd40ad90602ca5b">TTI::TCK&#95;RecipThroughput</a>) const</>}>
Returns the cost estimation for alternating opcode pattern that can be lowered to a single instruction on the target.

In <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/x86">X86</a> this is for the addsub instruction which corrsponds to a Shuffle + Fadd + FSub pattern in IR. This function expects two opcodes: <code>Opcode1</code> and <code>Opcode2</code> being selected by <code>OpcodeMask</code>. The mask contains one bit per lane and is a <code>0</code> when <code>Opcode0</code> is selected and <code>1</code> when Opcode1 is selected. <code>VecTy</code> is the vector type of the instruction to be generated.

</MemberDefinition>

### getArithmeticInstrCost {#a713bb53f77454635f44dd95c53fc8684}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getArithmeticInstrCost (unsigned Opcode, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; Ty, <a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bb">TTI::TargetCostKind</a> CostKind=<a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba59b32ea7b6f10564abd40ad90602ca5b">TTI::TCK&#95;RecipThroughput</a>, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/targettransforminfo/operandvalueinfo">TTI::OperandValueInfo</a> Opd1Info=&#123;<a href="#afa38851d75434d1476444ac93f94cb4ca9c0eecea29e9fa58e4dac7ee32b9b2ac">TTI::OK&#95;AnyValue</a>, <a href="#a733fb237f3037c95ed59de6055b176c5a2bc39e3785b29fe7bc4af768842a2072">TTI::OP&#95;None</a>&#125;, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/targettransforminfo/operandvalueinfo">TTI::OperandValueInfo</a> Opd2Info=&#123;<a href="#afa38851d75434d1476444ac93f94cb4ca9c0eecea29e9fa58e4dac7ee32b9b2ac">TTI::OK&#95;AnyValue</a>, <a href="#a733fb237f3037c95ed59de6055b176c5a2bc39e3785b29fe7bc4af768842a2072">TTI::OP&#95;None</a>&#125;, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; &gt; Args=&#123;&#125;, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; CxtI=nullptr, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/targetlibraryinfo">TargetLibraryInfo</a> &#42; TLibInfo=nullptr) const</>}>
This is an approximation of reciprocal throughput of a math/logic op.

A higher cost indicates less expected throughput. From Agner Fog&#39;s guides, reciprocal throughput is &quot;the average number of
clock cycles per instruction when the instructions are not part of a
limiting dependency chain.&quot; Therefore, costs should be scaled to account for multiple execution units on the target that can process this type of instruction. For example, if there are 5 scalar integer units and 2 vector integer units that can calculate an &#39;add&#39; in a single cycle, this model should indicate that the cost of the vector add instruction is 2.5 times the cost of the scalar add instruction. <code>Args</code> is an optional argument which holds the instruction operands values so the <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#aa0d69e81725c10fa5407f0bf34462068">TTI</a> can analyze those values searching for special cases or optimizations based on those values. <code>CxtI</code> is the optional original context instruction, if one exists, to provide even more information. <code>TLibInfo</code> is used to search for platform specific vector library functions for instructions that might be converted to calls (e.g. frem).

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l01334">1334</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp/#l00940">940</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp">TargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getArithmeticReductionCost {#a421ee26483edf3fd0cd1dca34513f45e}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getArithmeticReductionCost (unsigned Opcode, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/vectortype">VectorType</a> &#42; Ty, std::optional&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/fastmathflags">FastMathFlags</a> &gt; FMF, <a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bb">TTI::TargetCostKind</a> CostKind=<a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba59b32ea7b6f10564abd40ad90602ca5b">TTI::TCK&#95;RecipThroughput</a>) const</>}>
Calculate the cost of vector reduction intrinsics.

This is the cost of reducing the vector value of type <code>Ty</code> to a scalar value using the operation denoted by <code>Opcode</code>. The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/fastmathflags">FastMathFlags</a> parameter <code>FMF</code> indicates what type of reduction we are performing:
<ul>
<li>Tree-wise. This is the typical &#39;fast&#39; reduction performed that involves successively splitting a vector into half and doing the operation on the pair of halves until you have a scalar value. For example: (v0, v1, v2, v3) ((v0+v2), (v1+v3), undef, undef) ((v0+v2+v1+v3), undef, undef, undef) This is the default behaviour for integer operations, whereas for floating point we only do this if <code>FMF</code> indicates that reassociation is allowed.</li>
<li>Ordered. For a vector with N elements this involves performing N operations in lane order, starting with an initial scalar value, i.e. result = InitVal + v0 result = result + v1 result = result + v2 result = result + v3 This is only the case for FP operations and when reassociation is not allowed.</li>
</ul>

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l01580">1580</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp/#l01215">1215</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp">TargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
The expected cost of compare and select instructions. If there is an existing instruction that holds Opcode, it may be passed in the &#39;I&#39; parameter. The <code>VecPred</code> parameter can be used to indicate the select is using a compare with the specified predicate as condition. When vector types are passed, <code>VecPred</code> must be used for all lanes. For a comparison, the two operands are the natural values. For a select, the two operands are the <em>value</em> operands, not the condition operand.
</SectionUser>

### getInlineCallPenalty {#a2eae79e5ad5916c4e64cb73eb0b27323}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>unsigned TargetTransformInfo::getInlineCallPenalty (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> &#42; F, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/callbase">CallBase</a> &amp; Call, unsigned DefaultCallPenalty) const</>}>
Returns a penalty for invoking call <code>Call</code> in <code>F</code>.

For example, if a function F calls a function G, which in turn calls function H, then getInlineCallPenalty(F, H()) would return the penalty of calling H from F, e.g. after inlining G into F. <code>DefaultCallPenalty</code> is passed to give a default penalty that the target can amend or override.

### getMinPrefetchStride {#a8dcadecc95e9e49f77a70ab8b99a8c35}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="unsigned TargetTransformInfo::getMinPrefetchStride (unsigned NumMemAccesses, unsigned NumStridedMemAccesses, unsigned NumPrefetches, bool HasCall) const">
Some HW prefetchers can handle accesses up to a certain constant stride.

Sometimes prefetching is beneficial even below the HW prefetcher limit, and the arguments provided are meant to serve as a basis for deciding this for a particular loop.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="NumMemAccesses">Number of memory accesses in the loop.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="NumStridedMemAccesses">Number of the memory accesses that <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scalarevolution">ScalarEvolution</a> could find a known stride for.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="NumPrefetches">Number of software prefetches that will be emitted as determined by the addresses involved and the cache line size.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="HasCall">True if the loop contains a call.</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
This is the minimum stride in bytes where it makes sense to start adding SW prefetches. The default is 1, i.e. prefetch with any stride.
</SectionUser>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
The cost of a partial reduction, which is a reduction from a vector to another vector with fewer elements of larger size. They are represented by the llvm.experimental.partial.reduce.add intrinsic, which takes an accumulator and a binary operation operand that itself is fed by two extends. An example of an operation that uses a partial reduction is a dot product, which reduces two vectors to another of 4 times fewer and 4 times larger elements.
</SectionUser>

### getRegisterClassForType {#a623cced59353f83cc5eaba4068c57694}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>unsigned TargetTransformInfo::getRegisterClassForType (bool Vector, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; Ty=nullptr) const</>}>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
the target-provided register class <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/callingconv/#abdf8cf606905c10634e831390981b0ed">ID</a> for the provided type, accounting for type promotion and other type-legalization techniques that the target might apply. However, it specifically does not account for the scalarization or splitting of vector types. Should a vector type require scalarization or splitting into multiple underlying vector registers, that type should be mapped to a register class containing no registers. Specifically, this is designed to provide a simple, high-level view of the register allocation later performed by the backend. These register classes don&#39;t necessarily map onto the register classes used by the backend. FIXME: It&#39;s not currently possible to determine how many registers are used by the provided type.
</SectionUser>

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l01175">1175</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp/#l00767">767</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp">TargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.

  prototype={<>InstructionCost TargetTransformInfo::getShuffleCost (<a href="#af46433d0e36d3f80afc3a8c67b5c53ec">ShuffleKind</a> Kind, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/vectortype">VectorType</a> &#42; Tp, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; int &gt; Mask=&#123;&#125;, <a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bb">TTI::TargetCostKind</a> CostKind=<a href="#a706f223f760b55668fbae74202b816bba59b32ea7b6f10564abd40ad90602ca5b">TTI::TCK&#95;RecipThroughput</a>, int Index=0, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/vectortype">VectorType</a> &#42; SubTp=nullptr, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/arrayref">ArrayRef</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; &gt; Args=&#123;&#125;, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; CxtI=nullptr) const</>}>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
The cost of a shuffle instruction of kind Kind and of type Tp. The exact mask may be passed as Mask, or else the array will be empty. The index and subtype parameters are used by the subvector insertion and extraction shuffle kinds to show the insert/extract point and the type of the subvector being inserted/extracted. The operands of the shuffle can be passed through <code>Args</code>, which helps improve the cost estimation in some cases, like in broadcast loads. NOTE: For subvector extractions Tp represents the source type.
</SectionUser>

### preferPredicatedReductionSelect {#a8e8f7af4c35e8c6bc6e9a4f0850a7847}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::preferPredicatedReductionSelect (unsigned Opcode, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; Ty, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/targettransforminfo/reductionflags">ReductionFlags</a> Flags) const</>}>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
True if the target prefers reductions select kept in the loop when tail folding. i.e. loop: p = phi (0, s) a = add (p, x) s = select (mask, a, p) vecreduce.add(s)
</SectionUser>

As opposed to the normal scheme of p = phi (0, a) which allows the select to be pulled out of the loop. If the select(.., add, ..) can be predicated by the target, this can lead to cleaner code generation.

### shouldMaximizeVectorBandwidth {#a525b5174ebf7ac1db045dde5f579ddcb}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::shouldMaximizeVectorBandwidth (<a href="#a8bb3b1ccf19b8c85429b777dfa4a0166">TargetTransformInfo::RegisterKind</a> K) const</>}>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
True if the vectorization factor should be chosen to make the vector of the smallest element type match the size of a vector register. For wider element types, this could result in creating vectors that span multiple vector registers. If false, the vectorization factor will be chosen based on the size of the widest element type. <code>K</code> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> Kind for vectorization.
</SectionUser>

<SectionDefinition>

## Vector Predication Information


Whether the target supports the evl parameter of VP intrinsic efficiently in hardware, for the given opcode and type/alignment.

(see LLVM Language Reference - &quot;Vector Predication Intrinsics&quot;). <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/use">Use</a> of evl is discouraged when that is not the case.

### isProfitableToSinkOperands {#ae553d04f4c990459f9827950e6c71e75}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::isProfitableToSinkOperands (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; I, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallvectorimpl">SmallVectorImpl</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/use">Use</a> &#42; &gt; &amp; Ops) const</>}>
Return true if sinking I&#39;s operands to the same basic block as I is profitable, e.g.

because the operands can be folded into a target instruction during instruction selection. After calling the function <code>Ops</code> contains the Uses to sink ordered by dominance (dominating users come first).

### isVectorShiftByScalarCheap {#aca4d7e4051f7cb81a1e79bb1e25f03d5}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool TargetTransformInfo::isVectorShiftByScalarCheap (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; Ty) const</>}>
Return true if it&#39;s significantly cheaper to shift a vector by a uniform scalar than by an amount which will vary across each lane.

On x86 before AVX2 for example, there is a &quot;psllw&quot; instruction for the former case, but no simple instruction for a general &quot;a &lt;&lt; b&quot; operation on vectors. This should also apply to lowering for vector funnel shifts (rotates).

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h/#l01831">1831</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/analysis/targettransforminfo-h">TargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp/#l01434">1434</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/analysis/targettransforminfo-cpp">TargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
